item.title: Markdown
item.description:
Theoretical information

Markdown is a lightweight markup language for creating formatted text using a plain-text editor. John Gruber and Aaron Swartz created Markdown in 2004 as a markup language that is appealing to human readers in its source code form Markdown is widely used in blogging, instant messaging, online forums, collaborative software, documentation pages, and readme files.

The initial description of Markdown contained ambiguities and raised unanswered questions, causing implementations to both intentionally and accidentally diverge from the original version. This was addressed in 2014, when long-standing Markdown contributors released CommonMark, an unambiguous specification and test suite for Markdown.

Basic information about Markdown

To create a title, use the sign ( # ), for example:

1 # This is heading 1 2 ## This is heading 2 3 ### This is heading 3 4 #### This is heading 4

To make the text bold, enclose it in double asterisks:

    - This text is **bold**.

To set an italic font for the text, enclose it in single asterisks:

    - This text is *italic*.

To set bold and italicized text, enclose it in triple asterisks:

    - This is text is both ***bold and italic***.

An unordered (bulleted) list can be formatted using stars or dashes:

1 - List item 1 2 - List item 2 3 - List item 3

To nest one list into another, add an indent for the elements of the child list:

1 - List item 1 2 - List item A 3 - List item B 4 - List item 2

The ordered list can be formatted using the appropriate numbers:

1 1. First instruction 2 1. Second instruction 3 1. Third instruction

To nest one list into another, add an indent for the elements of the child list:

1 1. First instruction 2 1. Sub-instruction 3 1. Sub-instruction 4 1. Second instruction

The Markdown syntax for an embedded link consists of a part [link text] representing the hyperlink text, and a part (file-name.md ) ‚Äì the URL or the name of the file to which the link is given:

   [link text](file-name.md)

Markdown supports both embedding code fragments into a sentence and placing them between sentences in the form of separate fenced blocks. Fenced code blocks are an easy way to highlight syntax for code snippets. General format of fenced code blocks:

1 language 2 your code goes in here 3

Upper and lower indexes:

    ùêª indexe 2

it is written as
H~2~O

2 exposent 10

        it is written as

                     2^10^

In-text formulas are made similarly to LaTeX formulas. For example, the formula sin2(ùë•) + cos2(ùë•) = 1 will be written as

        $\sin^2 (x) + \cos^2 (x) = 1$

Off - line formulas: sin2(ùë•) + cos2(ùë•) = 1

{#eq:eq:sin2+cos2} —Å–æ —Å—Å—ã–ª–∫–æ–π –≤ —Ç–µ–∫—Å—Ç–µ ¬´–°–º–æ—Ç—Ä–∏ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É–ª—É ([-@eq:eq:sin2+cos2]).¬ª it is written as

1 $$

2 \sin^2 (x) + \cos^2 (x) = 1

3 $$ {#eq:eq:sin2+cos2} 4 5 –°–º–æ—Ç—Ä–∏ —Ñ–æ—Ä–º—É–ª—É ([-@eq:eq:sin2+cos2]).

Markdwon and the other languages

to build a table on markdwon use :

    header|hearder|header
    ---|:---:|---:
    content |conetent | content 
    content2 |conetent2 | content2

conclusion

Markwon is a library for Android that renders markdown as system-native Spannables. It gives ability to display markdown in all TextView widgets ( TextView, Button, Switch, CheckBox, etc), Notifications, Toasts, etc. No WebView is required. Library provides reasonable defaults for display style of markdown but also gives all the means to tweak the appearance if desired. All markdown features are supported (including limited support for inlined HTML code, markdown tables and images).

labraries:

MArkdown GUIDE

item.title: üëã Version control systems (git)
item.description:
import libr
print('hello')

Version control systems.

General concepts

Version Control System (VCS) is used when several people work on one project. Usually, the main project tree is stored locally, in other words, the Version Control System (Version Control System, VCS) is software that allows you to track changes in documents, if necessary, roll them back, determine who and when made corrections, etc. The article discusses the types of VCS, the principles of their operation, and also provides examples of software products.

Centralized and distributed version control systems

  1. Centralized version control systems: These are client-server applications where a project repository exists in a single instance and is stored on the server. It was accessed through a special client application. Examples of such software products include CVS, Subversion.
  2. Distributed Version Control System (DVCS): It allows you to store a repository (a copy of it) with each developer working with this system. In this case, you can allocate a central repository (conditionally), to which changes from local ones will be sent and, with it, these local repositories will be synchronized. When working with such a system, users periodically synchronize their local repositories with the central one and work directly with their local copy. After you make enough changes to the local copy, they (the changes) are sent to the server. In this case, the server, most often, is chosen conditionally, because in most DVCS there is no such thing as a “dedicated server with a central repository”. The two most well-known DVCS are Git and Mercurial.

Get Started

What are Git and GitHub?

Git is a version control system that has appealed to almost everyone, from developers to designers. GitHub can be considered a social network for storing code. This is a real Mecca for techies. Here you can practice development and come up with something of your own, find a lot of open-source projects, advanced technologies, various functions and designs. On GitHub, you learn and participate in other projects, store code for work or school, take the code of other projects and delve into all the details.

Basic git commands

The Git version control system is a set of command-line tools. They can be accessed from the terminal by entering the git command with various options.

Because Git is a distributed version control system, you can back up your local storage by simply backing up or archiving. The most commonly used git commands are:

‚Äì creation of the main repository tree:

   git init

‚Äì get updates (changes) of the current tree from the central repository:

  git pull

‚Äì pushing all the changes made to the local tree to the central repository:

  git push

‚Äì view the list of modified files in the current directory:

  git status

‚Äì view current changes:

  git diff

‚Äì saving current changes: ‚Äì add all modified and/or created files and/or directories:

  git add .

‚Äì delete the file and/or directory from the repository index (the file and/or directory remains in the local directory):

  git add –∏–º–µ–Ω–∞_—Ñ–∞–π–ª–æ–≤

‚Äì —É–¥–∞–ª–∏—Ç—å —Ñ–∞–π–ª –∏/–∏–ª–∏ –∫–∞—Ç–∞–ª–æ–≥ –∏–∑ –∏–Ω–¥–µ–∫—Å–∞ —Ä–µ–ø–æ–∑–∏—Ç–æ—Ä–∏—è (–ø—Ä–∏ —ç—Ç–æ–º —Ñ–∞–π–ª –∏/–∏–ª–∏ –∫–∞—Ç–∞–ª–æ–≥ –æ—Å—Ç–∞—ë—Ç—Å—è –≤ –ª–æ–∫–∞–ª—å–Ω–æ–π –¥–∏—Ä–µ–∫—Ç–æ—Ä–∏–∏):

   git rm –∏–º–µ–Ω–∞_—Ñ–∞–π–ª–æ–≤

‚Äì saving added changes:

‚Äì save all added changes and all modified files:

   git commit -am '–û–ø–∏—Å–∞–Ω–∏–µ –∫–æ–º–º–∏—Ç–∞'

‚Äì save the added changes with a comment via the built-in editor:

    git commit

‚Äì creation of a new branch based on the current one:

   git checkout -b –∏–º—è_–≤–µ—Ç–∫–∏

  • Switching to a branch:

     git checkout –∏–º—è_–≤–µ—Ç–∫–∏

(if you switch to a branch that is not already in the local repository, it will be created and linked to remote)

‚Äì push changes to a specific branch to the central repository:

   git push origin –∏–º—è_–≤–µ—Ç–∫–∏

‚Äì merging the branch with the current tree:

   git merge --no-ff –∏–º—è_–≤–µ—Ç–∫–∏
  • Delete a branch:

‚Äì removal of a local branch already merged with the main tree:

   git branch -d –∏–º—è_–≤–µ—Ç–∫–∏

  • Forced deletion of a local branch:

     git branch -D –∏–º—è_–≤–µ—Ç–∫–∏

  • Deleting a branch from the central repository:

     git push origin :–∏–º—è_–≤–µ—Ç–∫–∏

GitHub is also a hosting web service for Git repositories. GitHub hosts the main repository of all projects. From this repository, participants copy their work. If you’re familiar with centralized source control systems (such as Team Foundation Server, SharePoint, or Visual SourceSafe), you’ll notice that Git uses a unique workflow and specialized terminology to support a distributed model. For example, Git does not block files, as is usually the case when a file is taken in for editing or checked in after editing. In fact, Git takes changes into account at a thinner level by comparing byte-by-byte files.

Details can be found :

  • üëâ –û—Ç–∫—Ä—ã—Ç—å —Å–≤–æ–π git-hub
  • üìö **—É–ª—É—à–∏—Ç—å —Å–≤–æ–∏ –Ω–∞–≤–∏–∫–∏ –æ git **
  • üí¨ –ó–Ω–∞—Ç—å –≤—Å–µ –æ ** Git** or Git-guide
  • üê¶ Twitter: @git-twitter @Likendln #git-academy

Networking and Server Solutions

Git uses the network only for exchange operations with remote repositories.

The following protocols can be used:

git-protocol (URI scheme - git:) - an open protocol that requires the presence of a running git daemon on the server (supplied with Git), the protocol does not have means of user authentication; SSH (ssh:) - uses user authentication using key pairs, as well as a built-in Unix-system “main” SSH server (sshd), on the server side it is required to create accounts with git as a shell; HTTP and HTTPS (http:, https:) ‚Äì uses the curl tool (for Windows , shipped with git), and its HTTP authentication capabilities, as well as its support for SSL and certificates. In the latter case, you need to work on the server side of a web application that acts as a layer between the Git commands on the server and the HTTP server (among them Is WebGitNet, developed on the MVC 4 ASP.NET). In addition to supporting the server-side push and pull commands, such web applications can also grant read-only access to the repository through a web browser.

item.title: Display Jupyter Notebooks with Academic
item.description:
from IPython.core.display import Image
Image('https://www.python.org/static/community_logos/python-logo-master-v3-TM-flattened.png')


print("Welcome to Academic!")

Welcome to Academic!

Install Python and JupyterLab

Install Anaconda which includes Python 3 and JupyterLab.

Alternatively, install JupyterLab with pip3 install jupyterlab.

Create or upload a Jupyter notebook

Run the following commands in your Terminal, substituting <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER> and <SHORT-POST-TITLE> with the file path to your Academic website folder and a short title for your blog post (use hyphens instead of spaces), respectively:

mkdir -p <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
cd <MY-WEBSITE-FOLDER>/content/post/<SHORT-POST-TITLE>/
jupyter lab index.ipynb

The jupyter command above will launch the JupyterLab editor, allowing us to add Academic metadata and write the content.

Edit your post metadata

The first cell of your Jupter notebook will contain your post metadata (front matter).

In Jupter, choose Markdown as the type of the first cell and wrap your Academic metadata in three dashes, indicating that it is YAML front matter:

---
title: My post's title
date: 2019-09-01

# Put any other Academic metadata here...
---

Edit the metadata of your post, using the documentation as a guide to the available options.

To set a featured image, place an image named featured into your post’s folder.

For other tips, such as using math, see the guide on writing content with Academic.

Convert notebook to Markdown

jupyter nbconvert index.ipynb --to markdown --NbConvertApp.output_files_dir=.

Example

This post was created with Jupyter. The orginal files can be found at https://github.com/gcushen/hugo-academic/tree/master/exampleSite/content/post/jupyter
